title: Effect of climate dependent flux.
text: example show sedproxy can used reproduce study Löwemark et al 2008, illustrates effect climate dependent changes flux foraminifera resulting proxy record. brief, create pseudo-proxies rescaled version GISP2 Greenland ice-core d18O record. compare records 2 different hypothetical foraminifera: 1 optimum temperature close maximum temperature record, flux declines temperatures drop; second optimum near lowest temperatures record whose flux increases temperature drops.

title: Effect of climate dependent flux.
text: first use simple step-change climate show effect changes flux foraminifera recovery step proxy record. Löwemark et al. compare warm optimum cold optimum taxa, additionally one whose flux influenced temperature. also compare 4 different levels sediment mixing. keep sedimentation rate constant vary mixing depth, keep mixing depth fixed 10 cm vary sedimentation rate. use functions dplyr tidyr packages run forward model combination experimental setups different parametrisation. Create matrix habitat.weights taxon. Löwemark et al set flux 100 10 optimal suboptimal conditions respectively. sedproxy absolute values don’t matter, relative values normalised use weights. stochastic term forward model default zero variance need set clim.signal, timepoints, habitat.weights, sedimentation rate. bioturbation depth defaults 10 cm. Plot results Löwemark Fig.1 using ggplot.
code: clim.in <- ts(matrix(rep(c(1, 2), each = 50000))) timepoints <- seq(45000, 55000, 100) # setup a data.frame/tibble where each row represents 1 pseudo-proxy expts.fig1 <- crossing(   SAR = c(6.66, 10, 20, 50),   taxon = c("warm_opt", "constant", "cold_opt") )  expts.fig1 ## # A tibble: 12 × 2 ##      SAR taxon    ##    <dbl> <chr>    ##  1  6.66 cold_opt ##  2  6.66 constant ##  3  6.66 warm_opt ##  4 10    cold_opt ##  5 10    constant ##  6 10    warm_opt ##  7 20    cold_opt ##  8 20    constant ##  9 20    warm_opt ## 10 50    cold_opt ## 11 50    constant ## 12 50    warm_opt warm_opt.wts <- ifelse(clim.in == 1, 100, 10) cold_opt.wts <- ifelse(clim.in == 2, 100, 10)  # set these weights constant no.wts <- clim.in no.wts[,] <- 1 results.fig1 <- expts.fig1 %>%    group_by(SAR, taxon) %>%    # create a pseudo-proxy for each combination of SAR and taxon   do({     PFM <- ClimToProxyClim(       clim.signal = clim.in,       timepoints = timepoints,       # the function switch can be used to select the correct habitat weights       # depending on the value of taxon       # within a do() call, columns of the dataframe are accessed        # using .$       habitat.weights = switch(.$taxon,                                warm_opt = warm_opt.wts,                                cold_opt = cold_opt.wts,                                constant = no.wts),       sed.acc.rate = .$SAR)     # the last expression in do() should create or access a data.frame.      # One dataframe will be created for each combination of SAR and taxon,      # these are then combined together at the end.     PFM$simulated.proxy     }) %>%    ungroup() %>%    mutate(     # convert taxon and SAR to factors for plotting     SAR = factor(SAR),     taxon = factor(taxon, ordered = TRUE,                    levels = c("constant", "cold_opt", "warm_opt"))) results.fig1 %>%    ggplot(aes(x = timepoints, y = simulated.proxy,              colour = SAR, group = SAR)) +   geom_line() +   coord_flip() +   scale_x_reverse() +   facet_wrap(~taxon) +   labs(title = "Step change climate input")

title: Effect of climate dependent flux.
text: Create habitat weights function climate matrix 2 nominal taxa, 1 warm temperature optimum, 1 cold. assume simple Gaussian temperature response taxon maximum abundance flux certain optimum temperature declines abundance away can use dnorm optimum temperature mean. standard deviation controls steeply abundance drops away optimum.
code: wts <- tibble(timepoints = as.numeric(time(clim.in.gisp)),               warm_opt = dnorm(clim.in.gisp, -2, 1),               cold_opt = dnorm(clim.in.gisp, -0, 1))  wts.long <- wts %>%    gather(taxon, wt, -timepoints)  wts.long %>%    ggplot(aes(x = timepoints, y = wt, colour = taxon)) +   geom_line(alpha = 0.75)+   scale_color_manual(     values = c("cold_opt" = "blue",                "warm_opt" = "red")) +   theme_bw() +   labs(title = "Flux for warm and cold adapted taxa")

code: pfm.warm <- ClimToProxyClim(clim.signal = clim.in.gisp,                     timepoints = timepoints,                     habitat.weights = wts$warm_opt,                     sed.acc.rate = 10)  pfm.cold <- ClimToProxyClim(clim.signal = clim.in.gisp,                     timepoints = timepoints,                     habitat.weights = wts$cold_opt,                     sed.acc.rate = 10)  # Access the bits we want to plot warm_opt <- pfm.warm$simulated.proxy warm_opt$taxon <- "warm_opt"  cold_opt <- pfm.cold$simulated.proxy cold_opt$taxon <- "cold_opt"  pfm.warm.cold <- rbind(warm_opt, cold_opt) pfm.warm.cold %>%    ggplot(aes(x = timepoints, y = simulated.proxy, colour = taxon)) +   geom_line() +   # add the original climate signal   geom_line(data = gisp2.ann,             aes(x = age.yr.bp, y = temperature.rescaled,                 colour = "gisp2"), linetype = 1) +   # reverse the y axis so that warm is up   scale_y_reverse() +   scale_color_manual(     values = c("cold_opt" = "blue",                "warm_opt" = "red",                "gisp2" = "Darkgrey")) +   theme_bw() +   labs(title = "Rescaled GISP2 with pseudo-proxies from warm and cold adapted taxa")

what: What is a “proxy forward model” and what is “sedproxy”?
title: Introduction to sedproxy
text: proxy forward model numerical model takes hypothetical “true” climate time-series simulates processes proxy creation retrieval. output simulated proxy time-series resemble true proxy look like given assumed true climate. sedproxy R package implements forward model climate proxies archived marine sediments. model described Dolman, . M. Laepple, T.: Sedproxy: forward model sediment-archived climate proxies, Climate Past, 14(12), 1851–1868, https://doi.org/10.5194/cp-14-1851-2018, 2018. tutorial intended get started using sedproxy illustrate possible applications.

title: Introduction to sedproxy
text: main function sedproxy package ClimToProxyClim Climate--Proxy-Climate, first argument clim.signal. “assumed true” past climate proxy record modelled. output GCM, ESM, simple stochastic time series. matrix rows corresponding years - recent year top, going back time go matrix (sediment column!). example columns matrix represent months year, generally columns can also represent “habitats” different depths ocean proxy creation process might take place. sedproxy package contains example input climate taken Trace21k climate model run. closest model grid box core MD97-2141, foraminiferal Mg/Ca record (record 41 Shakun et al. 2012, Rosenthal et al., 2003). model data “time-forward” order need reverse order read , convert °C Kelvin. title: Introduction to sedproxy
text: habitat.weights define relative abundance flux climate signal carriers (e.g. foraminiferal shells) corresponding habitats (months) different columns input climate. example, particular taxa might abundant warm summer months winter.
code: hab.wts <- 1+cos(seq(pi, 3*pi - 2*pi/12, length.out = 12)) hab.wts <- hab.wts / sum(hab.wts) plot(hab.wts, type = "b")

title: Introduction to sedproxy
text: bioturbation depth bio.depth sedimentation rate sed.acc.rate control amount smoothing takes place due mixing sediment. marine sediment cores currently measured estimate bioturbation depth. default use value 10 cm close mean observed locations measured particle tracers. sedimentation rate can estimated set -core depths age estimates. example use sedimentation rate 10 cm / kyr together sediment slice thickness (called layer.width sedproxy) implies sampling interval 100 years.

title: Introduction to sedproxy
text: sedproxy forward model simulates measurement error simple normal/Gaussian distributed random variable, argument sigma.meas sets standard deviation error. set 0.25 °C Additionally, inter-individual error modelled normally distributed error term, sigma.ind, set 1 °C. argument n.samples controls number signal carriers (e.g. forams) measured together single sample. inter-individual error scaled square root n.samples mean effectively taken number individuals, 30.

title: Introduction to sedproxy
text: use sedproxy examine influence number forams per sample number samples measured per depth/timepoint/sediment slice. Combine three different measurement strategies plot.
code: pfm.30 <- ClimToProxyClim(   clim.signal = clim.in,   timepoints = req.timepoints,   #calibration.type = "MgCa",   sed.acc.rate = 50,   habitat.weights = hab.wts,   sigma.meas = 0.26, sigma.ind = 2,   n.samples = 30,   n.replicates = 300)  pfm.5 <- ClimToProxyClim(   clim.signal = clim.in,   timepoints = req.timepoints,   #calibration.type = "MgCa",   sed.acc.rate = 50,   habitat.weights = hab.wts,   sigma.meas = 0.26, sigma.ind = 2,   n.samples = 5,   n.replicates = 300)   # Here we take a shortcut. Instead of actually simulating the measurement of 6 samples at each timepoint we just shrink sigma.meas by sqrt(6) and multiply the number of forams by 6.  pfm.5x6 <- ClimToProxyClim(   clim.signal = clim.in,   timepoints = req.timepoints,   #calibration.type = "MgCa",   sed.acc.rate = 50,   habitat.weights = hab.wts,   sigma.meas = 0.26 / sqrt(6),   sigma.ind = 2, n.samples = 6*5,   n.replicates = 300)  pfm.120 <- ClimToProxyClim(   clim.signal = clim.in,   timepoints = req.timepoints,   #calibration.type = "MgCa",   sed.acc.rate = 50,   habitat.weights = hab.wts,   sigma.meas = 0.26,   sigma.ind = 2, n.samples = 120,   n.replicates = 300)  pfm.10x12 <- ClimToProxyClim(   clim.signal = clim.in,   timepoints = req.timepoints,   #calibration.type = "MgCa",   sed.acc.rate = 50,   habitat.weights = hab.wts,   sigma.meas = 0.26 / sqrt(10),   sigma.ind = 2, n.samples = 10*12,   n.replicates = 300) combined.pfms <- bind_rows(`5 forams` = pfm.5$everything,                            `30 forams` = pfm.30$everything,                             #`6*5 forams` = pfm.5x6$everything,                             `120 forams` = pfm.120$everything,                             `10x12 forams` = pfm.10x12$everything,                             .id = "measurement.strategy") %>%    mutate(measurement.strategy =             factor(measurement.strategy,                   ordered = TRUE,                   levels = c("5 forams", "30 forams", "120 forams", "10x12 forams")))  combined.pfms %>%    filter(stage %in% c("simulated.proxy")) %>%    ggplot(aes(x = timepoints, y = value, group = factor(replicate))) +   geom_line(alpha = 0.01) +   facet_wrap(~measurement.strategy)

title: Introduction to sedproxy
text: can take mean standard deviation across replicates timepoint plot instead.  finally can summarise error measurement strategy.
code: mean.error <- combined.pfms %>%    group_by(stage, timepoints, measurement.strategy) %>%    summarise(mean = mean(value),             sd = sd(value))   mean.error %>%    filter(stage %in% c("simulated.proxy")) %>%    ggplot(aes(x = timepoints, y = mean)) +   geom_line() +   geom_ribbon(aes(ymax = mean + sd, ymin = mean - sd),               alpha = 0.2, colour = NA) +   facet_wrap(~measurement.strategy) +   theme_bw() mean.error %>%    filter(stage %in% "simulated.proxy") %>%    group_by(stage, measurement.strategy) %>%    summarise(mean.error = mean(sd)) %>%    knitr::kable()

what: Simulate sediment archived proxy records from an input climate signal. — ClimToProxyClim
title: Simulate sediment archived proxy records from an input climate signal. — ClimToProxyClim
text: ClimToProxyClim simulates creation proxy climate record climate signal assumed true. following aspects proxy creation currently modelled. Seasonal bias encoding proxy due interaction climate seasonality seasonality life cycle organism encoding climate signal (e.g. Foraminifera Mg/Ca ratios, phytoplankton Alkenone unsaturation indices). Bioturbation sediment archived proxy. requested timepoint, simulated proxy consists weighted mean climate signal time window determined sediment accumulation rate sed.acc.rate bioturbation depth bio.depth defaults 10 cm. weights given depth solution impulse response function (Berger Heath, 1968). Aliasing seasonal inter-annual climate variation onto bioturbated (smoothed) signal. proxies measured small number discrete particles seasonal inter-annual climate variation aliased proxy record. example, Foraminifera life-cycle approximately 1 month, record something like mean temperature single month. Mg/Ca measured e.g. n.samples = 30 individuals, measured proxy signal mean 30 distinct monthly mean temperatures thus stochastic sample true mean climate. Measurement noise/error added pure Gaussian white noise process mean = 0, standard deviation = sqrt(sigma.meas^2 + sigma.ind^2/n.samples). Additionally, random bias can added realisation proxy record. Bias simulated Gaussian random variable mean = 0, standard deviation = meas.bias. randomly generated bias value applied timepoints simulated proxy record, multiple replicate proxies generated (n.replicates > 1) replicate different bias applied. ClimToProxyClim returns one replicates final simulated proxy well several intermediate stages (see section Value ).

title: Simulate sediment archived proxy records from an input climate signal. — ClimToProxyClim
text: ClimToProxyClim returns object class "sedproxy.pfm", list three elements: dataframe simulated.proxy dataframe smoothed.signal dataframe everything dataframe simulated.proxy contains single realisation final forward modelled proxy, well intermediate stages original climate signal requested timepoints. dataframe smoothed.signal contains block averaged version input climate signal, defaults 100 year means set parameter plot.sig.res. useful plotting resulting simulated proxy. dataframe everything contains multiple replicates pseudo-proxy records requested. data "long form", column "stage" inidcating proxy stage input climate resolution column "value" giving values. Named elements returned proxy record: timepoints Requested timepoints clim.signal.ann Input climate signal requested timepoints annual resolution clim.signal.smoothed Input climate signal regular time intervals resolution = plot.sig.res clim.timepoints.ssr Input climate signal requested timepoints, smoothed resolution = plot.sig.res proxy.bt Climate signal bioturbation proxy.bt.sb Climate signal bioturbation habitat bias proxy.bt.sb.inf.b Climate signal bioturbation, habitat bias, calibration bias proxy.bt.sb.inf.b.n Climate signal bioturbation, habitat bias, measurement error proxy.bt.sb.sampY Climate signal bioturbation, habitat bias, aliasing inter-annual variation proxy.bt.sb.sampYM Climate signal bioturbation, habitat bias, aliasing inter-annual intra-annual variation monthly temperatures depth habitats proxy.bt.sb.sampYM.b Climate signal bioturbation, habitat bias, aliasing inter-annual intra-annual variation monthly temperatures depth habitats, calibration bias proxy.bt.sb.sampYM.b.n Climate signal bioturbation, habitat bias, aliasing, measurement error simulated.proxy Final simulated pseudo-proxy, proxy.bt.sb.inf.b.n n.samples = Inf, proxy.bt.sb.sampYM.b.n n.samples finite observed.proxy True observed proxy (supplied)
